marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Des Barres, Joseph F. W. (Joseph Frederick Wallet), 1722-1824

Map of Mahone Bay area. This map is an excellent example of Desbarres' tendency to arbitrarily give names to places and features that don't seem to occur elsewhere in the historical record; Gloucester Isle is Oak Island, Royal George Island is Tancook Island, etc. Sailing directions: "This Bay is full of the finest Harbours, and there are deep Passages within almost every Island in it, with convenient Anchorage for all kinds of Shipping. To sail from the southward into Prince Harbour When you are as high up as Royal George Island, Steer for Robinsons Rock (which is always above water) untill the North Point of Louisa Island opens with the North end of William Henry Island whence you may Shape your Course to any part of the Harbour & Anchor at pleasure in 4, 6, or 9 Fathoms of Water good holding Ground. There are Several good Channels leading into the Royal Arm About the Middle part of it S W ½ S 300 Fathoms distant from the South end of Jarvis Isle & E ½ S distant 600 Fathoms, from the South Point of Barrington Island, lies a Ledge dry at Low Water. The Navigation into Cumberland Arm, Chester and the other Harbours in this Bay is so easy & safe, that the sole Inspection of the Draught will give every Information necessary on the Subject."

There are 8 known variations or states of this chart. Ours does not match any of them. Notable features of our copy: land is darkly shaded and heavily stippled, imprint March 1, 1779, PL. 17 (upper right). These features indicate it is likely between the 7th and 8th known states.

There are two scale bars on the map, one in Miles, the other in Nautical Miles. Map reads with North facing to the top Right corner of the map. The sailing directions cover the top left corner of the map, so there was a guess on where the top corner is to record the top left corner coordinate.
